ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Water, Little Water. We see Little Water grow from a tiny dew drop into a large ocean.
We learned the word tiny. Let’s revisit that word since that has something to do with the game we’ll play today.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the tiny Vocabulary Card to revisit the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures of water and say if it’s a lake, a river, a cloud, rain, or dew.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach/Model Ask children to give a thumbs-up if the picture shows a tiny drop of water or a thumbs-down if it does not. Model by showing children running water and drops of water from a faucet.
Ask Show a picture card and ask the question on the back. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Have a child place the card in the correct category.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Bodies of Water Review all of the different places you can find water. Invite children to think of other places where they could find water and say what they know about it.
For children who may have a hard time identifying the water in the picture, describe what a person might do on or in that water. Give up to three clues.
Have children choose three picture cards and sort them from large to tiny. Invite children to explain why they sorted the cards in the way they did.

Give children extra time for peer-to-peer conversation. Encourage children to work in pairs, comparing and contrasting the pictures. Remind children to take turns speaking, with one person actively listening while the other speaks. Remind children that it’s okay to use all the languages they both know when talking with a peer who is also multilingual.
For children who may not be able to stay on task, have them sit next to you. Give the child the responsibility of holding the picture card while the children are identifying what is shown.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread Water, Little Water. We learned that Little Water started as a tiny drop, but it kept trying until it turned into an ocean, and then climbed up to the sky!
When we persist in a task, we keep trying until we finish it.
In today’s activity, we will look at pictures of people trying to do different things. We will describe what they are doing and talk about why it is important to keep trying.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show a picture card and ask the question on the back. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Persisting in a Task Talk together about tasks that children need to do every day and how they persist in those tasks to make sure that they reach a goal. Give examples that you do every day, e.g., learning a new word, trying a new game or activity, or picking up all of their toys at the end of play time.

If the activities in the card are too difficult or are not developmentally appropriate for some children, guide them to say what they see in the picture and say whether they think the child in the picture will succeed at the task.
Invite children to turn and talk with a peer about a task that was difficult at first, but became easier the more times they tried doing it.
Speak slowly and pause when you are giving the instructions, to give children time to process the different directions. Have children repeat the different directions with you.

Before a lesson, set up a signal (such as touching the tip of the nose or patting the top of the head) with children that they can give you if they’re having trouble focusing. If they give the signal during the lesson, you can allow them to change seats, stand up, or something else that will help them get back on track.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread the book Water, Little Water. We listened to Little Water and his adventures.
Today, we learned that words in different languages can sound alike and have the same meaning.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the Cognates Strategy Card to revisit cognates.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we are going to look at pictures and say what we see. Then we are going to guess what the cognate is for the name of what we see.
We will look at pictures as we do this activity. We use a camera to take pictures. In Spanish, the word for camera is cámara. Cámara is a cognate for camera.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show a picture card and ask the question on the back. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Cognates Invite children to match cognates as you say them. Say the Spanish word and encourage children to say the English cognate for that word.

For younger or developmentally delayed children say both cognates and have them repeat both words after you. For example, ocean and océano. Be sure to say the Spanish cognate as it should be pronounced.
Challenge children to come up with cognates for the following words: class, fruit, artist, and photo. Provide hints where necessary.

Ask the Spanish speakers to raise their hand when they think they hear a cognate. Stop reading and discuss that cognate. Point out the subtle differences you hear between the Spanish and English words. Invite them to contribute cognates they might encounter every day.

Encourage children to draw a scene that includes an ocean. Provide writing materials so that children can also write as you spell ocean and océano. Provide assistance where necessary. Invite children to color and decorate their drawings.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the informational poster You Can Help! We learned some ways to help take care of Earth. We also learned the word recycle.
Let’s talk about that word again. It will help us as we do our activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the recycle Vocabulary Card to revisit the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures of different objects and say if they should be recycled or thrown in the trash. Then we will decide in which of these color bins the object should go. Here are some examples of what we would put into the different color bins:

section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Blue: This bin is for plastic bottles, aluminum cans, and glass jars.
Green: This bin is for paper and cardboard.
Gray: This bin is for food scraps and used juice boxes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card, and then ask the question on the back of the card. Offer children extra challenge or support questions as needed.
Sort Give the picture card to place in the correct column.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Do you recycle when you are at home? What kinds of objects do you recycle?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Support children by having a physical or written display of the objects that should be recycled versus the objects that should be thrown in the trash.

Have children come up with other examples of objects that might be recycled as opposed to being thrown in the trash. Challenge children to guess which bin (blue, green, or gray) the object should go into. Provide assistance where necessary.

Have children say the color of the bins in their home language as they identify where the trash should go. An extra challenge would be to also have them say the name of the object in the picture in their home language.

Children need a lot of movement every day to meet the sensory needs of their developing central nervous systems. Offer alternative and flexible seating so that children can move around more easily. Some examples of alternative seating are beanbag chairs and cushions.
